Nowoczesne narzędzia IT, w tym gry i grywalizacja wspomagające nauczanie dorosłych jako źródło konkurencyjności Fundacji MIERO

The project "Modern IT tools supporting adult education, including games and gamification as a source of competitiveness of the MIERO Foundation" is aimed at educators, trainers, and volunteers of the MIERO FOUNDATION employed on the basis of a contract of employment, civil contract or voluntary agreement. The participants of the project are people who have the motivation to lead classes in games and gamification in the future and use other modern IT tools in the process of adult education, in particular in the areas of entrepreneurship and decision-making.
Statistical data show that in Europe, the industry that generates the most new professions, we can include IT industries and all industries cooperating with digitization [Source: Foresight Publication of Personnel of Modern Economy, PARP, 2009]. This digitization and new IT tools are more and more connected with education. In the future, it is therefore inevitable linking education with new technology.
"Game" can become a tool supporting the education process. Research show that the greatest pleasure comes from the process of participating in the game / game through the uncertainty of the results that eventually take place in it (W. Holmes et al., Neuroeducational research in the design and use of games-based teaching, vol. 1, Portugal 2013 , p. 236). Implementation of elements of gamification into the learning process using games fostered increasing the attractiveness of the learning process, and thus increasing the motivation and commitment of the students in educational activities (Z. Bieńkowska, Game that is hard to resist - can science be addictive?).
On the basis of the above knowledge, the European development plan of the MIERO Foundation has the following project objectives:
- implementation of new teaching tools in the form of games and gamification, in particular in the field of entrepreneurship education and decision-making.
- implementation of new IT teaching tools, including mapping, cloud,
- raising the competence of MIERO Foundation educators and volunteers, in particular in the use of games and gamification and new IT tools in adult education,
- introduction of new programs in the area of modern IT tools in adult education as well as games and gamification in teaching entrepreneurship and decision-making,
- giving the European dimension to the organization.
These goals will be achieved through the following activities:
- Participation of 5 employees in the training in the UK in the field of games and gamification.
 - Participation of 3 employees in the training in Portugal in the field of modern IT tools used in adult education.
The introduction of new training areas in the MIERO Foundation, including implying games and gamification in teaching entrepreneurship and decision-making and new IT tools supporting the teaching processes of already functioning trainings will be the result. 
The impact of the project will be local, national and international.
The methods used in the project are a method of critical analysis of materials received during the trainings, the survey method (during the evaluation questionnaire), SWOT analysis method - analysis of strengths and weaknesses, threats and opportunities to undertake work on the project (used to reduce project risk).
Long-term benefits result primarily from new skills and digital qualifications of participants, which in turn will affect the Foundation's growing competitive position, according to "Human Capital is the Foundation's Capital".

Boosting careers of animation young artists with video mapping

The European creative sectors of animation and digital arts are drivers for creativity, innovation, growth and employment. However these sectors remain structurally weak and are not sufficiently competitive, on a global scale. This is due, in great part, to a failure to retain young talent that comes out of Europe’s high quality higher education system, attracted to the American and Japanese creative clusters. The Euranim project will develop concrete answers to these challenges, focusing on structuring the European animation sector around innovative digital technologies. The Euranim partnership comprises European universities of Art and Design, from five different countries, coordinated by the social enterprise Rencontres Audiovisuelles in Lille (FR). Euranim brings together more than 60 partners from the creative industries, public institutions and universities. The project will provide about 100 young animation artists with new digital skills thanks to an ambitious programme of eight artistic residencies in five European countries, focusing on the teaching of “video mapping”. This technique is still emerging and consists of projecting animated images onto physical structures, usually onto the facades of notable, historic buildings in order to exhibit and celebrate their heritage. Euranim will enhance the career prospects and facilitate the mobility and cross-cultural exchange of more than 400 young digital artists and staff working on the project via the organisation of five international cultural events, which will attract more than 45.000 people. Eight showcasing events will disseminate the results of the project activities and enable a sustainable network to be built. These showcases will demonstrate the opportunities offered by animation and video mapping in terms of artistic creativity, commercial use and wider societal benefit. Euranim will produce several evaluations of the sector in order to further support its development and economic impact.

Digital divide is currently hindering the widespread use of digital fabrication knowledge and technologies in the European cultural and creative sectors, especially in the field of design, arts and crafts.Technologies such as 3D printing and 3D scanning have recently opened new development and innovation opportunities for creative sectors. This phenomenon has been described as the third industrial revolution in as much as it is expected to radically change the production and distribution status quo, and strongly influence society as a whole, from a cultural, social and economic platform.Made@EU has undertaken the following main activities in order to remove existing barriers for the widest use of digital fabrication technologies amongst European creatives:• Creation and development of education materials in order to provide designers and craftsmen with digital the skills and know-how necessary to integrate digital technologies into their existing workflows;• Development of a workshop programme focused on digital technologies for the creative community;• Creation of residency programmes facilitating cross-European mobility of creators and generating international opportunities for emerging talent;• Increasing the circulation of European design and craft through 3 exhibitions.• Exploring the potential of innovative web-based business models for European creators.• Developing visibility for all achievements of note developed within the Made@EU framework in major events in design and creativity across Europe and beyond;• Development of an online platform aimed at on-going promotion of European craft and design and a marketplace ecosystem where individuals can promote their creations. Made@EU’s main results: - Creation of a platform to store and disseminate all project documentation. - Enhancing the Fablabs.io platform to store and disseminate the educational materials with an increase of 7.000 registered users during the project duration reaching a total of 10k registered users and 10k monthly visits.- Creation of a market place for the promotion of European craft and design. – Development of a collection of educational materials: 14 unique projects documentation including 28 videos and 500 pictures– Organisation of five workshops in Barcelona, Plymouth, Paris, Budapest, Amsterdam with the participation of 66 talented European Creatives.
Placements in Environmental and Traditional Skills

The Placements for Environmental and Traditional Skills project (PETS) brings together a consortium of UK VET colleges providing vocational training in environmental skills and traditional skills and crafts. The project will offer vocational students in these subjects inspiring and educational 4-week work placements with our experienced European host partners. The project also offers VET tutors the opportunity to undertake 7-day staff training visits to European host partners, to learn from their training methods, share experience and form lasting mutually benefical partneships. The project will fund 4-week placements for 47 environmental students and 55 craft students. PETS will also fund 7-day staff training placements for 18 teachers from environmental courses and 26 craft tutors (all from VET courses level 1-3).

This application benefits from over 10 years of Grampus promoting environmental and traditional skills and craft placements through the Leonardo da Vinci programme. This application and consortium combines the experience of delivering two certified IVT projects ‘Training in Contemporary Applications of Traditional European Crafts’ (TICATEC) and ‘Developing Environmental Skills In Rural Europe’ (DESIRE) within the Lifelong Learning Programme. (mobility certificate UK/09/LLP-LdV/MC/Z007) 

Host countries represented in the consortium are Czech Republic, Slovakia, Cyprus, Germany, Romania, Iceland, Slovenia ,Bulgaria Ireland and Turkey.

Participant students and recent graduates will develop a higher degree of self confidence, put theory into practice, gain new skills, improve existing skills and competences, inspire a renewed interest in their chosen subject, gain new language skills and complete a CV enhancing placement which will improve employment prospects and/or enable an informed progression to higher level study.

Participating staff will benefit from placing their own training in a wider European context. Travelling tutors will not only explore new skills, methods, approaches and techniques but will also share their own experiences with host organisations. This experience will give staff access to new ideas and approaches to training which will have a positive impact on their own training delivery. This will ultimately benefit vocational students of the tutor and enable the tutor to pass on new skills and information with a broader European scope.

The objectives of the project are to: 1 Provide a period of ‘real work’ experience for beneficiaries studying environmental and craft courses in the UK at VET level. 2. To ensure that this period of European experience is of relevance to the participant’s course of study and can be accredited as such. 3. To increase the appreciation in beneficiaries of the benefits of European cooperation and the fact that we are facing similar challenges across Europe. 4. To provide beneficiaries with sufficient time and support to increase competencies in key environmental and craft skills being used on the placement. These include:

Environmental Skills: planting, coppicing, footpath design and construction, countryside furniture construction (bridges, steps benches etc), biodiversity assessments and species identification, basic surveying, habitat management, organic sustainable food production.

Craft Skills: weaving, embroidery, silversmithing, blacksmithing, ceramics, wood carving, green wood construction, traditional building techniques (natural materials), 

 5. To develop a sustainable European VET partnership (hosts, UK colleges and Grampus) which can share experience and develop future cooperation projects. 6. To increase the employment prospects of participating students through gaining real-work experience and laying the foundation for language skills 7. To enhance UK VET training provision in environmental and traditional skills by providing 7-day staff placements for tutors with relevant European hosts.

The project management methodology for the PETS consortium is consistent with the 2001 Recommendation on mobility for students, persons undergoing training, volunteers, teachers and trainers and the ten principles set out in in the European Quality Charter for Mobility.

Students are accredited as part of their UK course of study for the mobilities. All participant mobilities are recognised through the Europass certificate as well as the Europass CV and language passport. Host partners provide a minimum of four language lessons with professional tuition. All staff mobilities are recognised within an agreed CPD plan with their own organisations. Host partners also provide certification and a record of achievement in their own format as additional evidence of achievement.

Detailed learning agreements are drawn up prior to placement through discussion between participants, hosts and UK colleges. These provide a realistic benchmark against which the success of the project and placements will be evaluated.
entrepreneurship, employability and enterprising in a digital and gaming environment

1) Key Competences in VET
The partnership aims to create VET environments in which key competences such as entrepreneurship, including critical ability, independent decision making, problem solving and creativity, as well as digital literacy are present everywhere - where learners are challenged to reflect on their own performances and meet digital challenges within the classroom and beyond to prepare them better for future chances and opportunities in the work place. 
2) Relevant and high quality skills and competences
We aim to make a selection of 4 very qualitative skills clusters - so-called Triple E-skills that all relate strongly to entrepreneurship, employability and enterprises - skills that are relevant to the latter, that are determined and co-defined by companies and sector federations in 4 chosen sectors.
3) Open an innovative practices in a digital era
The partners will capitalize on existing and create brandnew hands-on digital tools: demonstrative videos, learning objects that support the skill acquisition in 4 areas and mini games that enhance skills acquisition - all these will be open source and thus open to use and complete for other stakeholders. In addition, innovative elements such as virtual or augmented reality will be considered for use where relevant. Also, the open badges system installed by Mozilla and Be Badges (Selor) plays an important role as in innovative aspects in the project. 

OBJECTIVES
This project is meant to support VET systems in the 4 countries involved through
1) More attractive education and training programs that are ..
2) .. in line with individual needs & expectations
3) The use of participatory approaches and ICT-based methodologies
4) New or improved processes of recognition & validation of competences

Consequently, the project aims to work on the following global objectives:
1. More entrepreneurial and digital skills in learners, companies and teachers
2. Better relationship with companies in VET environments

More specific objectives are: 
1. Bring awareness by demonstrating the relevance in the workplace of a number of carefully selected skills 
2. Boost acquisition of those skills providing a selection of content and target group-oriented and digital instruments (games)
3. Formally and officially validate the acquisition of skills by labour market and educational actors
4. Certificate the validated skills by a badges system

By doing all that, we focus on 2 crucial criteria:
- Co-creation: Involvement of students and companies as direct end users in the development of new tools and pathways (they co-design and co-create) – and involvement of the teachers-trainers as intermediaries, coaches of learners
- Digitization: We focus on innovative learning objects and digital tools of learning incl VR and AR. 

We will be organizing the project over 4 phases (awareness, acquitisition, validation and certification) and will bring forth 5 intellectual outputs, that will amongst other activities disseminated during 8 multiplier events.
Creëren van Volwaardige Leeromgevingen -  Uitwisseling voor en door Ervaren Trainers

The CRE-ATE project fits within the wider vision of Syntra West vzw that aims to offer high quality training for all learners by strengthening teachers in their role as trainer and coach. In view of the changed expectations and increasing diversity in the groups of learners, as well as the demand for specific support from the teacher in order to respond to this change appropriately, a shift to a rich and constructive learning environment required. To enhance the employability of the learners and to prepare them for their future careers in a real work environment, courses tailored to their possibilities and learning needs are the solution. In this way we want to enhance the motivation and learning ability of each individual student.

In the CRE-ATE project, 6 teachers and employees are offered the opportunity to learn from colleagues abroad, via 6 mobilities to Spain, Hungary, the Netherlands, Portugal and the United Kingdom. They will get inspired by job shadowings and exchanges with teachers and trainers who face similar challenges and tendencies. By experiencing themselves how other European training partners apply concrete tools and methodologies, we want to offer our trainers resources which they can use in their own teaching practice.

The topics that will be discussed are:

- Creating a rich and stimulating learning environment: providing individual feedback, coaching and advice outside the classroom setting (e.g. by using a learning platform, giving specific practical assignments and applying different ways to motivate the learners)
- The integration of 21st century skills (e.g. intrapreneurship, critical thinking, communication skills, entrepreneurial learning and sense of responsibility) into the courses: creating awareness of these skills and supporting the learners in practicing those skills in each lesson 
- ICT-supported teaching: the added value of ICT and the use of concrete tools, programmes and methodologies in order to differentiate in view of different learning abilities, learning styles and interests.

After each mobility activity, peer moments will be organized to transfer the acquired knowledge and insights to the entire organization. The new methodologies are also incorporated into practical staff trainings, linked to broad range of didactic skills in order to give all future trainers the confidence to apply the newly gained insights. At the end of the project, a final event will take place to have the participants testify about their European experience in view of a wide knowledge sharing and creating new learning dynamics in the entire organization.

A high benefit will be the perception of the Ernst-Litfass-School as a progressive media school at European level.

Grasping the Links in the Chain: Understanding the Unintended Consequences of International Counter-Narcotics Measures for the EU

Since the end of the Cold War there has been an explosion in the international drugs market and a consequent general desire to review and reform the existing international control regime. Academic understanding of the role of the drugs market in the international economy has increased, but the cumulative impact of counter-narcotics measures in transit chain countries between source and market remain poorly understood, nor are there many comparative studies of the manner that differing illicit drug economies work. These factors remain obstacles to understanding and eliminating the unintended consequences of current counter-narcotic policies, particularly since supply and demand-based counter narcotics measures are separated by the intermediary impact of the geographical 'transit chain' in most cases. This proposal offers the novelty of undertaking a comparative strategic study of two major drug markets, heroin and marijuana, through the prism of the transit chains that currently operate between Afghanistan and the EU and North Africa and the EU respectively, with a view to then evolving a more comprehensive counter-narcotics policy aimed at minimising the proliferation of unintended consequences. The proposal aims to bring this about via a combination of building up an up-to-date strategic model of how these two drugs markets currently operate, conducting interviews with counter-narcotics practicioners and field research in both the source and transit chain countries concerned, and then disseminating this research in the form of concrete policy recommendations via conference activity and publications, including a collection of conference papers and at least one major monograph.

The group of participants of the Project „We gain experience in Europe – work practice as an approach to modern job market” consists of 32 students of technical college Zespół Szkół Zawodowych im. Stanisława Staszica w Barlewiczkach. The students attend classes with the following specialities: motor vehicle technician, computer technician, feeding and gastronomic services technician, hotel technician, auto mechanic technician. Also, a group of 25 graduate students will join the Project. In May and October 2015 two group of 16 students are going to go on traineeship to Plymouth, Great Britain. Between March and June 2015, a group of 10 graduates is going to go on 3-months probation, and between September and November next group of 15 graduates is going to set off for the work practice. The partner of the project is Tellus Group Ltd from Plymouth, Great Britain – vocational course centre. 3rd grade students and graduates from our school will undergo the traineeship and practical training in Great Britain. The traineeship and probation will be connected with a practical training „Preparation for working life”, due to which students will be prepared to enter the job market. The course gives them an opportunity to obtain qualifications at APT Level 2 Award, a respectable European award. This eligibility is fitted to participant’s needs and capabilities. 

The participants choose the number and topics of credits that they want to obtain. The trainees, due to the prolonged stay in Plymouth, will have the opportunity to gain higher qualifications by choosing additional modules to pass. The youth from our school requires support, as the students come from rural areas and often from dysfunctional families or threatened by social exclusion. Many of them live in poverty. In January this year the unemployment rate in our county has reached 28,4%, while the unemployment rate in Poland totals 14%. Because of the tough family situation and places of residence, our students often are not able to face up to the requirements of modern job market.  Sztum county offers little possibilities for hiring graduates, that is why it can be observed than more and more young people migrate to other polish cities or countries for financial reasons. The lack of fluency in speaking English language and low level of professional and social competence limits occupational mobility of our students. For this reason, taking part in the proposed project is a great chance to leave the poverty and lack of education behind. The objectives of the project are compatible with European objectives Europa Strategy 2020. The objectives of the project represent preventing youngsters from precocious deserting educational system by the way of raising the level of crucial competence and abilities, including language and professional competence, which would raise the level of employment among 20-years-old graduates. The project will also help to minimize the number of people threatened by poverty and social exclusion, strengthen the international educational dimension, certification on the basis of learning effects, increasing youngster’s mobility, promoting European values, promoting awareness of foreign cultures and traditions, shaping attitudes towards openness and tolerance, learning about aspects of working in a culturally and socially different environment, pointing out the need of continuous enhancing qualifications. 



Expected results of the project: 

100% of trainees will undergo work practice in Plymouth (certificates)

100% of graduates will undergo probation in Great Britain (certificates)

100% of trainees and graduates will receive Europass Mobility documents

100% of trainees and graduates will receive a confirmation of obtained qualifications due to competence APT Level 2 Award

100% of trainees and graduates will take part in cultural and pedagogical preparation workshops

100% of trainees and graduates will enhance their qualifications. 

100% of trainees and graduates will enhance their language skills. 

100% of participants will be better prepared for beginning working life and entering job market.  

- developing the sill of team work, creativity, adjusting to a new situation, comprehensibility,

- a rise in the sense of affiliation to European Union owing to breaking through language barriers and enhancing self-esteem. 

-participating in the project will significantly increase the school’s prestige, as well as let it gain new experience in work education and organizing work practice. 



In order to support self professional development, students will gain new qualifications and work experience. Experiences obtained during the external practices and trainings are more and more important as a criterion for applying for a job. Traineeship in English companies and work practice provide perspectives for professional development and possibility to present education and compare it with other, European educational systems. The project is directed to students of ZSZiO Technical School in Żukowo of the following specialties: economic technician, IT technician, logistics technician, advertising technician. Month-long internships will take place in modern companies in Plymouth in Great Britain. Participants will develop the practical skills connected with their profession and will be given opportunities to confront theory with practice. At the same time, student will acquire key skills, such as second language communication, workplace communication, social skills and  cultural sensitivity skills, in particular those connected with accepting workplace diversity and preventing prejudice and racism. They will undergo basic law orientation; they will become familiarized with workers’ rights and responsibilities; they will learn how to pursue their rights abroad. Thanks to the project, the students will become more active professionally and will enjoy greater mobility with respect to their workplaces, jobs and even place of living. The abovementioned skills will be certified with proper documentation recognized in Great Britain and other EU countries (Europass Mobility, APT Awards).

The project is aimed at three specializations of our school: economics, information technology and tourism. The project will be implemented in cooperation with the partner organisation Tellus (Group) Ltd - Work Experience UK. There are 32 participants of the program (aged 17- 19): 6 in economics and 20 in information technology and 6 in tourism sector. The participants' selection criteria are clearly stated. During their stay in the UK the students will be accompanied by 2 teachers:  Mrs Ducka and Mrs Gurowiec/ Mrs Musiałek

The main objective of the project is placement implementation  in small and medium enterprises in Plymouth (the UK). The participants will be divided into two groups. The first group will consist of 16 students  ( 10 in IT,  6 in economics) and will stay in the UK from 1 March  2015 to 28 March 2015. In the second group there will also be 16 students (10 in IT , 6 in tourism) and they will  stay in the UK from 18 October 2015 to 14 November 2015.

Other priority objectives of the project are the following:

a. to acquire new qualifications and improve existing ones,

b. to acquaint participants with requirements imposed by European employers on employees,

c. to acquaint students with ways of functioning and management of small and medium enterprises. It would be helpful in supporting graduates in setting up and running their own companies and counteracting unemployment,

d. to develop students' skills and thus improve their situation in the labor market and increase their employability,

e. to match curriculum requirements and the needs of employers in the European markets,

f. to promote the idea of mobility in working life,

The project is based on the analysis of job markets needs and conclusions drawn from cooperation with local employers. It also takes into account current changes taking place in European job markets. We want to meet  requirements imposed by local and European employers on our graduates. Potential employer looks for enterprising, mobile people with good knowledge of foreign languages. Professional training and  skills are also essential here. Student will be able to receive employers' references and international certificates.

The placement will be mainly implemented in small and medium companies in Plymouth.

One of the priorities of our placement program is supporting graduates in setting up and running their own companies. The aim is going to be reached by the knowledge of companies organizational structures, their functioning and management.

 The process of education will be greatly accompanied by experience gained in companies. International placement allows not only to make observations, improve professional skills and gain professional experience but also to communicate  in English freely and to gain ability to move on the European job market as well.  Teachers will benefit in this field as well.

As a result the participants will increase professional and language skills. They will also acquaint themselves with part of the British job market. The participants of the project will receive the Europass Mobility certificate, employers' references and the certificate of attendance in the project . Each of the institutions participating in the project has the tasks assigned to. In addition, the project schedule has been created. The project will be evaluated  and monitored at its every stage and its results will be disseminated.

At local level, our project is in agreement with the needs of development strategy for the Silesian District (2000- 2020), where increasing mobility on job market and professional qualifications improvement are emphasized. At present, the Silesian District is developing dynamically as far as its economics is concerned; and foreign investment is essential here.

On national scale, our project supports actions promoting the spirit of enterprise among the young, whose careers might be the result of experience gained on the European job market.

For European perspective, the project supports and  complements EU member countries actions in the field of education and vocational training.

The goal of this project is a four-week apprenticeship in the UK for  students from Zespół Szkół nr 1 in Sanok.  Seven students from each of the following profiles : economic technician, logistical technician, hotel technician and nourishment and household technician will take part in the apprenticeship. That will total 28 students and 2 counsellors. The hosting organisation is Tellus Ltd., which is an organisation experienced in organising apprenticeships for students. The training course will take place in Plymouth in the UK. The project meets school needs (increasing the attractiveness and quality of teaching), students’s needs (increasing  personal, professional and linguistic competence, increasing job opportunities, providing equal chances), local employers’s needs (better workers in the local job market) and the local community’s needs (parents, local authorities).

The appretice will learn about the nature of a British company, management and work methods, occupational and safety hygiene regulations, vocational foreign language and governance typical for the UK. They will also develop the following qualities in real work conditions: propriety and dealing with customers, independence, industriousness, respecting work discipline, ability to work in a team, ability to plan one’s work and time managment, ability to organise one’s work place and ability to use a foreign language. The above skills will be characteristic of the profession, as they will be shaped in a specific work environment characteristic to the trade.

The theoretical knowledge acquired at school will be deepened by practical skills, and  the skills and certificates attained by students will make it easier for the future graduates to function in the job market. The project will help them  to find a job or run their own business. During the apprenticeship students should learn about the functioning of a company in the European labour market, understand the occupational requirements, resulting in  the satisfaction of customer needs. Taking part in this project will make the graduates  more confident in their relations with employers and customers.

Thanks to living with  host families, the apprentices will get to know the lifestyle of average British people, their culture, customs and leisure time activities. The apprentices will learn how to cope in new, sometimes extreme situations. The proper recruitment system will motivate students to improve their academic results and attendence. The apprentice will also attain points in the APT Awards system. It is a system developed to offer the participant job experience recognised in the EU. The general idea makes it a clear system to assess student’s skills, which supports the current pursuit of EU countries to standardise the marking scheme of  the practical skills of vocational school students. Using APT Awards will result in an easier and fairer job application procedure or the ability to continue education in EU countries. They will also increase their competence in the following fields: professional, linguistic, computer skills, organisational , social and personal.

The project will definitely:

- improve the quality of vocational training offered by Zespół Szkół nr 1 in Sanok,

- improve knowledge and professional skills of the participants,

- decrease the differences between academic knowledge and skills and competence expected by employers,

- teach about methods and techniques used in the UK,

- increase the employment prospects of the apprentices,

- increase the apprentices’ enterprising spirit and initiative,

- increase the apprentices’ mobility in the job market,

- improve English language skills,

- encourage the apprentices to take part in various forms of job training (also abroad),

- increase apprentices’ multicultural competence and show them how to live and work in a mulicultural environment,

- positively influence self-esteem,

- show the apprentices how to appreciate European Union membership.

Mobility activities of „Stiftung Bildung & Handwerk“ (SBH- Education and Crafts Foundation) are realized in the EU Programme „Erasmus+“ (2014 – 2020) in the framework of mobility for learners in vocational education and training, key activity 1 (KA1). 



SBH promotes mobility of learners within three different types of activities:

1. SBH provides opportunities for apprentices from companies throughout Germany to realize work placements abroad 

2. SBH continues colaboration on regional level with „Carl-Severing-Berufskolleg für Handwerk und Technik, Bielefeld“ and organizes work placements for 10 students as assistent in food technology to gain work experiences as well as to develop intercultural, social, personal and social competences. 

3. SBH promotes mobility for staff of vocational education and training centres belonging to SBH and working in the field of VET for disadvantaged young people.  SBH and partners organize within one – week study visits exchanges of experiences and discussions on pedagogical issues with regard to daily work. 

 

SBH act as promotor of individual mobility for apprentices, so as done within „Leonardo da Vinci“ with mobility certificate.  

We support apprentices from the sectors of administration, commerce, hotellry and gastronomy throughout Germany. 

Based on the wide range of vocational programmes in many different professional fields in our vocational training centres SBH has numerous contacts to companies throughout Germany. By the grant of ERASMUS + we promote 25 apprentices (in the second year of VET- process) to realize a four week work placement in one of our European partner countries: Bulgaria, Finland, Ireland, Italy, Spain, Hungary and the United Kingdom.  If apprentices or their companies have contacts in other European countries that can be used to realize the internship, too. 

SBH publishes the offer at the companies website, corresponding the standard of quality for so called „Poolprojekte“. 

Interested apprentices SBH are choosed within an interview via phone and on the basis of corresponding documentation (CV and letter of motivation).  

SBH offers pedagogical and intercultural preparation, if necessary language preparation, too. Therefor we decide depending on the place of domicile of the apprentice either to participate in a workshop at SBH Paderborn or to realize preparation via e-learning.    

SBH supports aprentices and their company during the whole process: starting with application for funding, planification,organization, preparation, realization and post evaluation. If wished by the company or the apprentices we coordinate a task to study during the work placement.

Requirements and aims of the work placement are established individually with every participant corresponding to his VET process.  The final programme for the stay abroad is coordinated among apprentice, company or vocational school and the partner institution abroad.  In situ abroad process is supervised by the partner organization in cooperation with a mentor for internship at the company abroad. Learning agreement will be established between all three parties to assure quality and as base for work. 

The aim is to promote flexibility and independece, to offer technical, intercultural and individual experiences. In contact with people, culture and language of hosting country apprentices develope knowledge and competences. 

Essential part of every work placement is post preparation: after the return from abroad participants present their impressions and experiences: either at SBH or at their company or at vocational school to develop sustainability about mobility. 



All partners and participants play an active role in the public to disseminate experiences within European mobility. 



To document activities, experiences, skills and competences, all aprticipants within all activities will get the Europass Mobility document.
Formare europeana in turism și alimentație publică

The present project intends to address the need of trainees of developing personal and professional abilities for a better integration on the European labour market that becomes more and more competitive. Other objectives of the project are improving linguistic competence of the participants and also facilitating the transition between formal education and professional training. Last but not least the validation of competence gained during their training abroad through transferable credits is addressed.The direct beneficiaries are 14 trainees from the 10th grade (16, 17 years old) who study Services and specialise in Tourism and Gastronomy. They will be organized into 2 flows of 7 and will be accompanied by a teacher.The training they will have in Great Britain contains activities designed to acquire abilities necessary for a chef  and an employee in an accommodation unit: making dishes of low complexity, mis-en place for breakfast and dinner, greeting clients, cleaning in an accomodation unit.This particular group age has been chosen as it has been considered that acquiring abilities necessary on the labour market has to be made gradually and at this age, students are in the middle of their training.The training will be done in Great Britain, the host organization being Tellus Group, a well-known provider of vocational training programmes which  has successfully provided and placed trainees in a wide variety of internships, vocational training placements and work-based learning since 2002. The host organization is going to provide a member responsible for monitoring students'progress using evaluation forms, questionnaires, interviews. The project is going to have an intermediary as well as a final evaluation. (final and intermediary evaluations).The abilities and skills acquired by students will be certified by Europass doscuments as well as by transferable credit ECVET. Students are also going to get a mark for the competence acquired.As a result of the project, trainees will have at the end of their training a portofolio and also a presentation of one of the themes of the training. (for example making a dish  they have learned during the training). The presentation can take the form of a power-point material, culinary exhibition) We consider that by developing the professional competence of the trainees, by increasing the opportunities trainees have on the real labour market, the indirect beneficiary of the project is the local community and by extension, society and the European labour market.

The project “Apprenticeship abroad is my opportunity” is aimed at students of the third form technical school of electronics and ICT profiles. Participating in the project gives the students a real chance to acquire knowledge, skills and professional qualifications, it increases the perspectives of finding employment in both domestic and European job markets and it enhances personal development.

Moreover, it supports the development of our school, especially in the field of vocational education and it aids the cooperation as well as the exchange of experiences on an international level. These kinds of contacts have an influence on the transference of different and often innovative educational solutions on the native ground in the form of learning content, services, training and the methods of lifetime learning.

The apprenticeship will take place in Plymouth in the centre of the vocational education Tellus Group. 20 students will take part, 10 from each class involved in the project. The recruitment will be based on clear rules. The students will be provided with international transport, insurance, accommodation, board and full mentoring from both the teachers of ZSEiO, who will be looking after the students during the apprenticeship and from the employers of the host organisation.

Before leaving the young apprentices will get organisational support, which will make their stay abroad easier. During the classes, they will boost their vocabulary and expressions needed for work and everyday life communication. They will also get basic information about the culture, traditions, customs and the economy of the country they are going to visit. They will be familiarised with the rules of the apprenticeship, the programme and regulations of their training, rights and obligations, safety rules during their journey and stay as well as cultural differences.

During their 2-week stay in Plymouth, the students will undergo vocational training called “Preparation for vocational life”. They will get to know the rules and regulations concerning health and safety at work in the UK, organisation of the workplace, personal and social competences, which are helpful in carrying out their work, methods of individual or group work organisation.
The ICT students will do tasks connected with designing and creating local computer networks as well as managing the data communication networks. The group of electronics students will do tasks connected with installing, maintenance and repair of electronic devices.

The apprenticeship will allow the opportunity to compare the European industry solutions with the ones used in Poland and to verify the theoretical knowledge in a practical aspect.
While taking part in the project, the students will develop their language competence, improve their communication skills and specific vocabulary. Staying with families and often participants of other courses who come from different countries, the students will learn the understanding of different cultures, openness and tolerance.
Each participant will receive the Europass Mobility document, which carefully describes the vocational and additional benefits the student acquired during the apprenticeship and a Certificate of completion issued by the host organisation.
The experience of the apprenticeship will definitely be of great significance for the students’ vocational and personal career.

Our school is located in in the environment which provides students and teachers with limited opportunities for personal and career development. Unfortunately, our region belongs to the least developed in Slovenia according to different indices. An enormous outflow of young people is a sad fact, which is due to poor variety of educational programs that are offered here and consequently fewer possibilities to find a job. We have been coping with the problem of reduced enrolment in our school and we believe that additional contents would be a good promotion of our school. Namely, this year a lot of younger students and their parents have showed a lot of interest in international mobility activities.
The participants of the project “Open your mind” will be students of Secondary School of Economics and Commerce Brežice attending programs of economic technician and logistics technician.  In both programs students of the 3rd year have to carry out a 2-week work placement. Therefore, the central activity of this mobility will be work placement of 20 students in companies abroad. All the students did their work placement in local companies in their 2nd year of school. It involved receiving and sending post, recording transactions in day books of a company /working with cash registers, manipulating databases and entering data, archiving documents, business correspondence and working with customers. An international experience means upgrading students’language, communication competences and work skills as well as personal qualities. The work placement of economic technician program students will refer to administration field.   Their work will consist of: sorting out the post, managing diaries, answering the phones, greeting clients, writing business letters, preparing presentations, using ICT in administration and using office devices (fax machine, copy machine, etc). The students of logistic technician program will fill in transport documentation and do logistic correspondence using ICT. 
As a part of Vocational matura exams students are obliged to make a project work, so the participants of this mobility will focus in their projects on comparison of Slovenian and English economy systems and on transposition of good business practices in the Slovenian environment. Through this experience students are expected to be additionally motivated to learn English for specific purposes, to develop their business sense and to become mobile within the European labour market. The objective to decrease early school leaving could be achieved through increased motivation of students, different teaching methods and actualisation of work and life, all of which is provided with this project. 
The “open your Mind” project is carried out by a coordinator cooperating with teachers of economics and logistics subjects and teachers of English. Tasks and responsibilities are assigned through the phase of application of candidates, choosing the participants and preparation for mobility as well as at mobility monitoring and post-mobility evaluation and dissemination. Results of the project will be presented by the students on “open door days”, on the information day, on “Festival of education” (“Festival izobraževanja”) and on technical days in primary schools. The model of cooperation with the Youth Centre Brežice (MC Brežice) and the Posavje Museum Brežice has proven as very successful in the context of presenting our work in international projects to the local community, so we intend to keep this model also for this project.

For several years our institution Janos Csere Apaczai Professional Secondary School has been seeking international partners who can give us a chance to join practical work in an English-speaking country. The situation has been particularly difficult since September 2013 because the professional curriculum requires completing a professional summer practice  on each course/year. The opportunities  of our small town with a population of 20,000 are especially limited in the field of the fast-improving Information Technology. So since September 2013 we have been looking for international partners on that particular area consciously. Beyond expanding professional vocabulary our aim is to learn about new ICT tools, softwares and hardwares.
 
 
In the frames of the project with the purpose mentioned above we are going to organize three trips for 16 students with 3 teacher escorts altogether. Since so far we have not had enough experience with any of the partners, the management of the project decided on short, 14-day mobility for the small groups.  Our  students are taking part in after-matura education, studying on the informatics branch and have their final examinations in English as a foreign language.
 
 
According to the expectations the trips will take place from 1 August 2014 to 31 July 2015. We are planning two trips for August (Malta and Italy) and one  for June (England).
 
 
As the result of the project we expect to get acquainted with  and  spread new technologies and ICT tools within our institution. We expect our students to improve their English, to extend their professional vocabulary. We expect the international practice to improve teaching Information Technology for both our students and our teachers. The independence and confidence of our students will grow, they will be able to apply their acquired knowledge on the home and international labour market. We wish to form a long-term relationship with at least one of our partners, which would expectedly raise the teaching standards of our school and at the same time it would improve the chances in both further education and finding a job.

Our cooperation with the English organization Tellus Group started a few months ago through very frequent e-mail and telephone correspondence. Shortly after the new Erasmus + program has been presented we thought it would be a perfect opportunity and possibility  for a project that could be of mutual interest. In this project our company FILIP M  will participate as a sending organization with 7 teachers and Tellus Group as a hosting partner.    
The name of our project is "Obtaining European experiences -improved language competencies
The possibility to be faced with greater and advanced countries provides opportunities each teacher, each individual who is involved in any kind of teaching, educating or involvement in language to widen, enhance and get better skills and knowledge .
The aims of this project would be: 
- increased foreign language competencies 
-enhanced employability and improved carrier prospects 
- increased motivation in participation in future formal and non formal teaching and training 
All participants who will be involved in the project will find ways to improve themselves as this is their second profession. They will share what they know, how they  perform their classes  and from their second activity that they have, they will  gain more experience better and improved ways of translation and interpretation.
Our  company together with the involved participants are hoping to gain the following competencies.
-improved language competencies
It means that after attending the training course  they can use all four language skills reading,writing speaking and listening better  and with great self confidence
-improved social and cultural competencies
The possibility to stay in a country as England can provide direct links to the social life, their habits, customs and culture which could influence  the teaching and could be presented better in front of the future students.
- greater ability for promotion of English language and culture
The fact that they will visit the country itself they will get closer image for  the language, people and their inheritance. In that way they can easily transfer to their students what they have actually seen
 -better teaching skills 
As our company is not very large but exists for 10 years now  this kind of experience would be excellent for future development and investment in better studying, training and giving chances that are rarely given  to the teacher. With improved working methodology  and practices, the participants would be actively involved and they will have unique possibility to hear, talk and communicate solely in English, but at the same time
-to present their knowledge
-how they teach
-what methods they  use in their teaching and translating activities
-what actions they take to make their attendants more interested
The mobility would take place from 20.04.2015 to 03.05.2015 with 7 participants at Plymouth, England

Vocational School Complex in Giżycko is the applicant of the project "Modern methods of teaching are the way to improve the quality of education". The implementation period is from 1st June 2015 to 6th June 2016.
Continuous improvement of the competences of teachers is one of the tasks of the school. Within the project has been planned departure of three of our teachers for a one-week methodological and lingual course, implemented in an EU country – Great Britain.
The main assumptions of the course are to improve the knowledge on methods, techniques, strategies and teaching styles that promote creative and motivating way to learn English, knowledge of current changes in the educational system of Great Britain and development of tendencies in English language teaching, improvement of English language skills, exchange of ideas and experience as well as cooperation with teachers of secondary schools from other European countries.
The objectives of the project are determined jointly by teachers and the headteacher, based on the needs of the school and its employees, so that the benefits of the trip apply not only to the participants but also to the whole institution.
The project will help to achieve the main goals which are to improve the quality of education in the Vocational School Complex in Giżycko in certain areas by improving the competence of teachers of English and to establish international cooperation.
The project will be attended by three teachers of English: Mrs Marta Tyszko, Miss Natalia Rommel and Mr Artur Wojnowski.
The immediate effect of the training will be methodological and lingual strengthening of the powers of the English teachers in terms of knowledge and skills to apply effective modern teaching methods and techniques, effective ways to increase student motivation for learning and learning organizations, recognize different learning needs of the student, development of learners autonomy, use of Information Technology and improvement of communication skills.
The teachers will use their knowledge and skills in school practice. This will increase the interest and motivation of students and contribute to their greater involvement and achieving better language skills. The transfer of experience and knowledge of the course will improve awareness among students about cultural diversity and awareness of young people to the opportunities offered by Polish membership in the European Union.
Implementation of the project will provide the opportunity to develop a model of raising professional and linguistic competencies among education staff with the use of international mobility, which will contribute to improving the quality of teacher education and training.
Implementation of the project and the actions taken by the teachers after returning from the course, aiming to implement the acquired knowledge and skills, will affect the positive image of the school in the local environment.
Implementation of the project will prepare the facility to begin international cooperation through  establishment of new experiences and contacts. In the longer term, the project will contribute to the implementation of activities in the field of international cooperation and the exchange of students of  Vocational School Complex in Giżycko with students from other countries and enhance their learning mobility.
The project refers to the purpose of the Erasmus+ programme in school education sector, takes into account the individual needs of the school and provides implementing new solutions observed abroad and contributes to the improvement of professional qualifications of the school staff.
Cognitive Optimization By Assistive Learning Tool.

In Europe, there are about 80 million people with disabilities, which means 1 person out of six. Among them, many are discriminated against in their daily life and this is the reason why the European Union has decided to set up laws and a strategy to provide equal opportunities. The "2010-2020 disability strategy " covers many different fields dealing with the renewal of competencies and employments providing member states with analysis, political guidances, information and many other types of help. The main aim is an increase of the employment rate of disabled people: this goal is embedded in the Europe 2020 strategy which targets a global employment rate of 75 % in 2020 compared to 69% in 2010. If we consider disabled people, their unemployment rate is twice higher than for people who are not disabled and one way to tackle the issue is to facilitate their access to qualifications and certifications.

This project will target IVET and CVET learners with cognitive disabilities. It means people who are dyslexic, suffering dysphasia, attention deficit disorders, high functioning autism, implementing functions disorders... the project will focus on EQF 3 level which is the first level for a vocational diploma. 

The main objective of the project will be to provide our target group with tools enabling them to have access to certifications in order to ease their professional inclusion.

With this project , we will design versatile apps likely to meet the needs of an heterogeneous group with learning difficulties and introduce digital technologies to these learners by developing innovative and customizable solutions to: 
- Facilitate the understanding of instructions and tasks to be carried out.
- Contribute to a better link between theoretical knowledge and their practical implementations.
- Facilitate memorizing.
- Enable the portability of tools in different environments.
- Help teachers/trainers to present the activities carried out  when oral expression is concerned.

In order to reach this goal, we will undertake several activities such as, at first, a comparative analysis, then the design of an assistive digital tool; a protocol of implementation will be devised in cooperation with stakeholders as well as a "training the trainers" programme and session.

The work and the outputs are innovative and will allow our organizations to strive to achieving equal opportunities for any type of learner. Each of our country has passed laws in favour of equal rights and opportunities for disabled and this project is certainly a way to help disabled, to whom up to now, very few solutions were proposed to move forward and get the chance of a smooth vocational inclusion as any other citizen. The use of the tools will bring new alternatives, resources  and practices.

Aims: 
The aim of the project is to create a best practice training resource representing a synergy between partners from different cultural backgrounds, working in different fields of education, training and youth. The BPTR will be useful for those working in Higher Education, Youth Work, School Education, in addition to those who work in a clinical setting.

Six participants from UK, Greece (x2), Lithuania, Romania and Turkey, will exchange workshops (x2) to develop a common understanding of Alexithymia, Deliberate Self Harm and Suicide in Young People and to up-skill those working with young people in different fields of education, training and youth, in order to address the Europe 2020 agenda regarding poverty and social exclusion, in terms of the reduction of early school leaving and improvement of academic attainment in young people. 

Objectives:
We will create a resource of best practice non-formal training bringing together different approaches in young people's well being support within the participant countries. This resource will include a comprehensive evaluation of the different practices exchanged and exploited during the lifetime of the project. At each partnership meeting (6 in total), the host partner will present 2 one-day workshops of best training practice in terms of how they help young people explore their feelings and empower them to make positive choices - to take more control in their lives. Each workshop will include a contribution from a young person to talk about their lived experience, having been the recipient of the host's workshops prior to the meeting. This resource will be presented at a final international conference in March 2017 in Siauliai, Lithuania.

Context / Background:
Early School Leaving and Low Academic Achievement is a priority of the Europe 2020 agenda, in terms of addressing issues of poverty and social exclusion.

Six  participants:
PADMA (UK): Mental Health Charity working with young people in schools
ZISPB (Lt): an NGO providing social and educational initiatives in the field of vocational rehabilitation for disadvantaged groups, especially young adults
SSP&MH (El): Non-profit scientific organisation providing high quality psychiatric support services and promotion of social inclusion in young people, particularly those with mental health issues
BEHDER (Tr): NGO working in field of Youth to improve health at local, regional and national levels
AUTH (El): Higher Education Institute using art therapies and workshops in the field of youth
BUCOVINA (Ro): NGO working in the field of education and young people

Description of Activities:
Each partner will bring a total of 3 persons to each externally hosted learning activity / transnational meeting (15 "mobilities" each partner); each partner will host a learning / transnational meeting.

Methodology in carrying out the project:
Each partner will prepare 2 one-day workshops in presenting their best training practice; emphasis being on the "bite-size" learning activities that can be practised, taken away, implemented and then evaluated prior to the next round of learning activity.

Evaluation to take place immediately after each meeting. Partners will share their learning with colleagues, who will evaluate the shared learning. Each participant will complete "learner diaries" following each partnership meeting to record the impact of the learning on their own personal and professional development. Local delivery of the workshops (translated into own language) will also be evaluated in order to address "fitness for purpose".

Description of results:
Short bite-size learning workshops & implementing the workshops upon return from the partnership meeting and evaluating them, will build substantive records regarding the impact of delivering the shared workshops within partners' own working practices, and further afield to stakeholders in the fields of education training and youth. 

Impact:
We will present an evaluated resource of shared best training practice at the final international conference and make available on the project web site. Each partner will make recommendations and report of activities to supplement the impact shared training has had and to explore the potential for developing an accredited common training programme that can be mapped to the EQF. 
Each partner will create an informal community committee to include a mental health professional, teacher, parent association member, young person (from school committee or youth committee) and a local authority young people service to build bridges between people in need and our specialised services to support future sustainability initiatives.

Longer term benefits:
We will explore the potential for the project to become a development of innovation in its own right, following completion of the project.

Long term, we see the outputs of the project to become embedded in the daily practices of each partner organisation.
Discourse Analysis with Unconditional Positive Regard

The aim of this project is the critical rethinking of practitioners who work with vulnerable adults. DAUPR will use discourse analysis and self-reflexivity as tools to enable practitioners to work from a position of unconditional positive regard (UPR) with their vulnerable adult client group.

It is well known that "Starting where your client is at" is one of the most important tenets of professional health and social work but developing an attitude of nonjudgmental acceptance is one of the most difficult tasks of being able to work with vulnerable adults. This project will deliver a 5-day short term training event to specifically tackle this issue.

The objective of the project is to create a CPD training resource for practitioners who work with vulnerable adults to enable them to work from a position of UPR.

We will deliver a 5-day learning event to 20 such practitioners from 4 different EU countries at an event in Plymouth, UK. The participants will receive Europass Mobility Certificates detailing the learning outcomes of the training programme. The training will be evaluated by all participants who will feed this back to local stakeholder committees.

Each partner will recruit at least 5 stakeholders who will form their local stakeholder committee to steer local delivery of the project. Each stakeholder committee will be briefed to follow the Plymouth Development Tool for Vocational Training (PDTVT) in order to assess fitness for purpose of the training programme.

Each partner participant will host a transnational meeting with 3 representatives from each partner in attendance. They will have the opportunity to meet the local stakeholders and observe how the hosting partner has adapted the training within their own organisation and the impact this training has had on its client beneficiaries.

Each meeting participant will submit a learner diary to ASTRA, the lead for dissemination, who will create a report for presentation at the end of the project.

In meetings the project's team will exchange good practices regarding working with their vulnerable adult client group. The meetings will be recorded and then transcribed in word files. Then they will be analysed with discourse analysis. ln that way team members will examine their own constructions about vulnerable adults in a self-reflexive way. At the same time the team will interact with each other and exchange best practice.

Evaluations will take place after each partner meeting. The 5-day short term staff training event will also be evaluated by attendees and all materials evaluated by the 5 local stakeholder committees in line with the PDTVT framework.

5 Participants
Mental Health Centre Agrinio, Greece – public body working in mental health
ODYSSEUS, Greece – centre for the prevention of abuse and promotion of psycho-social rehabilitation
Plymouth and District Mind, UK – mental health charity whose Recovery College works with vulnerable adults
ASTRA, Serbia – local NGO dedicated to the eradication of all forms of trafficking in human beings
SENTPRIMA, Slovenia - private institute for counselling, training and rehabilitation of people with disability, especially for people with mental health disorders.
 
By the end of the project we will have a robustly evaluated CPD (Continuous Professional Development – CVET) training programme that will have become embedded in each partner staff training curriculum and made available for all organisations and practitioners working with vulnerable adults.

Description of results:
A robust evaluation strategy will create substantive records regarding the impact of delivering the CPD programme within partners' own working practices and further afield to stakeholders in the fields of VET working with vulnerable adults.

The results of the project will form a CPD resource for those already working in this field and a training programme, plus materials and user guide for those new to the field, such as volunteers or new staff being inducted (IVET) into the partner organisation. The end result will be a resource that can be used by other organisations across EU available for download from the project web site.

Impact:
We will present an evaluated resource of shared best training practice at the local multiplier event conferences and make available on the project web site. Evaluation results will demonstrate impact to include use of tools such as WEMWBS (Warwick & Edinburgh Mental Well Being Scale) and KOLB Experiential Learning Cycle. Partners will inform policy and decision makers locally, nationally and internationally, via their extensive networks and in attending externally held conferences and meetings.

Longer term benefits:
We will explore the potential for the training to become an accredited programme post-completion of the project mapped to the EQF.
EMP:PATH: Exploring mindful parenting, a path for social well-being

There is a growing interest in mindfulness as a way of living with increasing scientific evidence of its value for optimal health and well-being. Since several years mindfulness is also being increasingly integrated into education. The evidence shows that as benefits educators and learners demonstrate increased resilience and ability to better cope with stress, difficult moments and relations. Educationalists agree on the fact that relationship needs to be nurtured long before the moment of crisis, both from the educators' side (teachers, parents, social workers) and the children side.
The project partners either had experience in mindfulness or in parents training and education and both were supportive to each other for the benefit of the project learning, process and results.

The project aimed at exchanging practices in the field of parenting, parents' education and mindfulness for children and schools, at learning from each partner’s experiences and practices as well as from what was available in their national contexts, at exploring the contact points for laying the foundation and verifying the feasibility for the development of a mindfulness course for parents based on the different approaches of the partners involved; at bringing mindful parenting to the attention of a wider audience and to get recognised as significant stakeholders in the field.

The project's core activities were local parents' workshops where the educators and parents together practiced mindfulness and together reflected on the impact on themselves as educators and persons. The impact is presented in a form of stories collected by the partners from some of the parents and educators that did attend the local workshops. The stories confirm the project hypothesis that the practice of mindfulness within the family context shows a number of benefits: calmer and more relaxed parents, better emotional regulation and enhanced relationships between the parents and the children.
The workshops were the way to network at local level, to reach out to parents, to implement into the local contexts the learning from the training activities undertaken in Austria (The Way of Council and Jon Kabat-Zinn); Mindful Self Compassion and .b in the UK; WakeUpSchool Project at the Plum Village in France as well as the famous method "Arguing Well" developed by CPP.

The partners' reflections and conclusions are collected in the Guidelines for Developing a Mindful Parenting Curriculum.
The Guidelines, the stories and much more are available for free through the project website http://www.mindfulness-in-parenting.eu that will continue to
exist.

The project was able to directly reach out to 1.030 parents and educators, with 87 local workshops and 149 hours of collective practice with the parents, those
impact is featured in 30 stories in the 4 languages.

A series of dissemination activities undertaken - through events, social media and personal contacts - were providing partners with the possibility to network
and connect with stakeholders in the filed of education and Mindfulness across Europe and also to be recognised as key stakeholder in the field, by being
invited to several events and be listed as providers of mindful parenting.

The local workshops are still taking place in the 4 countries and small thematic format are under development based on the parents and educators requests.
The partners are currently harvesting the results of the intensive work done and defining new partnership and cooperations for events and for even more
strengthening the relevance of Mindfulness in education. The results of the project are well embedded into the partners core activities thus reinforcing the
systemic impact obtained.
European Vocational Training - IES A Pinguela - 2018-20

CONTEXT  AND OBJECTIVES

Instituto de Enseñanza Secundaria A Pinguela (1.E.S. A Pinguela) (http://www.iesapinguela.es) is a public College located in Monforte de Lemas, a town on the north-west of Spain (Galicia), that offers secondary, bachillerato (16-18 yo) and VET (high and medium level). lt is located in a rural area which is under-industrialised  and we are committed to give to all our  students the opportunity to experience mobility in Europe to improve their competences and employability.
This project is aimed to VET students and teachers, having the following objectives:

1. For students , to validate On the Job training module (FCT) with a placement on a company abroad
2. To improve competence on the host country language
3. For teachers, to get updated on latest market products and techniques to be incorporated to their teaching
4. For IES A Pinguela to reinforce a network of european partners, to enrich mobility offers to students and teachers
S. For host partners to benefit form participants experience and know-how.

ACTIVITIES

IES A Pinguela offers 4 VET courses PEINADO Y COSMÉTICA CAPILAR (2 year+FCT), ESTÉTICA Y BELLEZA (2 year+FCT), GESTIÓN ADMINISTRATIVA (2year+FCT) and SISTEMAS MICROINFORMÁTICOS Y REDES (2 year+FCT)
Student mobilities will last for the duration of the whole FCT (10 weeks) to better meet objectives 1 and 2.

Oct-dec 2018: 1 student from SISTEMAS MICROINFORMÁTICOS in a company in the UK .
Apr-Jun 2019: 1 student from SISTEMAS MICROINFORMÁTICOS in a company in the UK , 2 students from GESTIÓN in companies in italy, 1 student from GESTIÓN in a company in France, 3 students from PEINADO in companies in Portugal, 1 student from ESTETICA in a company in Portugal.
Apr-Jun 2020: 1 student from SISTEMAS MICROINFORMÁTICOS in a company in the UK , 1 student from GESTION in a company in Italy, 2 students from PEINADO in companies in Portugal and 1 student from ESTETICA in a company in Portugal.
Teacher  mobilities  will be:
June 2018: one teacher of Beauty will do a one week period of job-shadowing  in a company in  Italy
June 2019: one teacher of Beauty will do one week of job-shadowing in a company in Italy and one teacher of Business and administration will do a job-shadowing  in a company in ltaly.

METHODOLOGY

A mobility commission will be formed by VET tutors, the project coordinator and the head of school; to assure that all professional families are involved . lt will carry on the following tasks: select participants , define training agreements , monitor work placements, evaluate and certify work-placements. This commission is responsible for running the project together with partners:

IIS Biagio Pascal supports the selection of companies and participants, facilitates communication between IES A Pinguela and host companies and cooperates in organizing the trip.
Host companies from IT, Administration and Hair & Beauty sectors: agree on the training program, designate a tutor in the company; collaborate in the evaluation of the participants and with the dissemination of the project.
Participants organise their trips supported by IES A Pinguela , take their linguistic, cultural and practical preparation both at IES A Pinguela and vía OLS , take responsabilities for the On the job training module and integrate on the social life of the destination city.

RESULTS AND IMPACT

- To improve professional, linguistic and personal competences far the participants
- To validate the on the job training module having  adquired  necesary learning outcomes
- To increase employment opportunities far participants
- To make participants European citizens
- To improve teaching methodology in VET

LONG TERM BENEFITS

- To consolidate mobility offer far VET students and teachers
- To built up a network of Colleges and companies across Europe.
- To get involved in partnership projects with schools and companies.
